title: Q5: Merkle Tree Performance Spike
description:
## Question
How fast is on-demand Merkle Tree generation from BTreeSet?

## Why This Matters
Stroma stores members in BTreeSet but needs Merkle proofs for ZK verification.
If generation is slow (>500ms), we need caching strategy.

## Test Scenario
```rust
let members: BTreeSet<Hash> = (0..N).map(|i| hash(i)).collect();
let start = Instant::now();
let root = generate_merkle_root(&members);
println!("Time: {:?}", start.elapsed());
```

## Decision Criteria
- < 100ms for 1000 members → GO: Generate on demand
- 100-500ms → PARTIAL: Cache in bot, invalidate on change
- > 500ms → NO-GO: Optimize or cache in contract

## Fallback Strategy
Cache Merkle root in bot, invalidate on membership changes.

## Implementation Tasks
1. Create docs/spike/q5/merkle.rs with Merkle Tree implementation
2. Create docs/spike/q5/main.rs benchmark (10, 100, 500, 1000, 5000 members)
3. Create docs/spike/q5/README.md and RESULTS.md
4. Add [[bin]] spike-q5 to Cargo.toml

## External Documentation
- Merkle Trees: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Merkle_tree
- ring crate (hashing): https://docs.rs/ring/latest/ring/
- sha2 crate: https://docs.rs/sha2/latest/sha2/

## Project Documentation (MUST READ)
- .cursor/rules/tech-stack.mdc - ring for HMAC, cryptographic libraries
- .cursor/rules/freenet-contract-design.mdc - On-demand Merkle generation pattern
- docs/ALGORITHMS.md - Merkle proof generation for ZK verification
- docs/spike/SPIKE-WEEK-BRIEFING.md - Q5 section

## Benchmark Requirements
- Multiple iterations for statistical significance
- Test tree generation, proof generation, proof verification
- Output timing table in RESULTS.md

## Deliverables
- docs/spike/q5/README.md
- docs/spike/q5/merkle.rs
- docs/spike/q5/main.rs
- docs/spike/q5/RESULTS.md (performance table + decision)

title: Q4+Q6: STARK Wasm and Proof Storage Spike
description:
## Question (Q4)
Can winterfell compile to Wasm and verify proofs performantly?

## Why This Matters
Determines if Freenet contract can verify ZK proofs (trustless) or if bot must verify (less trustless).
Q6 (proof storage) depends entirely on Q4 answer.

## Q4 Test Plan
1. Compile winterfell verifier to wasm32-unknown-unknown
2. If compiles: measure verification time for 10KB proof
3. Document compilation issues if any

## Q4 Decision Criteria
- Compiles + < 500ms verify → GO: Contract-side verification
- Compiles + > 500ms verify → PARTIAL: Client-side for now
- Does not compile → NO-GO: Client-side only

## Q6 Decision Matrix (Based on Q4)
| Q4 Result | Q6 Decision | Rationale |
|-----------|-------------|-----------|
| Contract verifies | Don't store proofs | Contract verifies on demand |
| Client verifies | Store outcomes only | Bot verifies, contract trusts |
| Partial (slow) | Store proofs temporarily | Verify once, then delete |

## Fallback Strategy
Bot verifies proofs before Freenet submission. Less trustless but functional.

## Implementation Tasks
1. Create docs/spike/q4/verifier.rs - Minimal STARK verifier using winterfell
2. Create docs/spike/q4/main.rs - Generate proof, verify, attempt Wasm compile
3. Create docs/spike/q4/README.md and RESULTS.md
4. Create docs/spike/q6/README.md and RESULTS.md (decision based on Q4)
5. Add [[bin]] spike-q4 to Cargo.toml

## External Documentation
- winterfell crate: https://docs.rs/winterfell/latest/winterfell/
- winterfell GitHub: https://github.com/facebook/winterfell
- STARK Proofs: https://starkware.co/stark/
- Wasm target: https://rustwasm.github.io/docs/book/
- wasm32-unknown-unknown: https://doc.rust-lang.org/rustc/platform-support/wasm32-unknown-unknown.html

## Project Documentation (MUST READ)
- .cursor/rules/tech-stack.mdc - arkworks/winterfell for ZK-proofs
- .cursor/rules/freenet-contract-design.mdc - STARK verification in contracts
- .cursor/rules/cryptography-zk.mdc - ZK proof requirements
- docs/spike/SPIKE-WEEK-BRIEFING.md - Q4 and Q6 sections

## Wasm Compilation Test
```bash
cargo build --target wasm32-unknown-unknown --release -p spike-q4
```

## Deliverables
Q4:
- docs/spike/q4/README.md
- docs/spike/q4/verifier.rs
- docs/spike/q4/main.rs
- docs/spike/q4/RESULTS.md (compilation + performance)

Q6:
- docs/spike/q6/README.md
- docs/spike/q6/RESULTS.md (decision based on Q4)

title: Q3: Cluster Detection Spike
description:
attached_molecule: hq-wisp-bpc
attached_at: 2026-02-01T06:05:22Z
attached_args: Validate Q3 spike: Verify docs/spike/q3/ has main.rs and RESULTS.md, run cargo check
dispatched_by: mayor

## Question
Does Union-Find distinguish tight clusters connected by bridges?

## Why This Matters
Cross-cluster vouching is MANDATORY for admission. Same-cluster vouches are rejected.
If cluster detection fails, the admission system breaks.

## The Bridge Problem (Test Scenario)
Cluster A (tight):  Alice, Bob, Carol (all vouch each other)
Bridge:             Charlie (vouched by Carol + Dave)
Cluster B (tight):  Dave, Eve, Frank (all vouch each other)

Union-Find result: 1 cluster (all connected)
Expected: 2 clusters (A and B are distinct)

## Decision Criteria
- 2 clusters detected → GO: Use Union-Find variant
- 1 cluster detected → NO-GO: Use fallback proxy rule

## Fallback Strategy
"Vouchers must not have vouched for each other directly"
- Simpler implementation, blocks obvious same-cluster vouching
- Trade-off: May reject some valid edge cases

## Implementation Tasks
1. Create docs/spike/q3/cluster.rs with Union-Find + alternatives
2. Create docs/spike/q3/main.rs test runner (7-member bridge scenario)
3. Create docs/spike/q3/README.md and RESULTS.md
4. Add [[bin]] spike-q3 to Cargo.toml

## External Documentation
- Union-Find Algorithm: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Disjoint-set_data_structure
- Community Detection: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Community_structure
- Louvain Algorithm: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Louvain_method

## Project Documentation (MUST READ)
- docs/ALGORITHMS.md - Graph theory foundations, cluster detection algorithm
- .cursor/rules/cluster-terminology.mdc - Internal vs external clusters
- .cursor/rules/security-guardrails.mdc - Cross-cluster vouching violations
- .beads/cross-cluster-requirement.bead - Full threat model
- docs/spike/SPIKE-WEEK-BRIEFING.md - Q3 section

## Deliverables
- docs/spike/q3/README.md
- docs/spike/q3/cluster.rs
- docs/spike/q3/main.rs
- docs/spike/q3/RESULTS.md (GO/NO-GO decision)

title: Audit: discovery-protocols.bead consistency with Q7 findings
description:
Audit .beads/discovery-protocols.bead for consistency with Q7 (Bot Discovery) findings:

## Q7 Key Findings:
- Decision: GO with registry-based discovery
- Phase 0: Single registry contract (<10K bots)
- Scale trigger: Shard at 10K+ bots (256 shards by contract hash)
- Discovery latency: < 1ms (requirement: < 5s)
- No heartbeat mechanism (stale entries acceptable)
- Registry tracks: bot contract_hash, size bucket, registered_at, epoch

## Update Requirements:
- Update discovery mechanism recommendation
- Document registry contract design
- Document sharding strategy for scale
- Update latency expectations
- Remove or clarify heartbeat requirements
- Add Phase 0 vs Phase 1+ migration path

## Deliverables:
- Updated .beads/discovery-protocols.bead
- Document changes in commit message

## Related Docs:
- docs/spike/q7/README.md
- docs/spike/q7/RESULTS.md

title: Audit: security-constraints.bead consistency with Q8/Q9/Q13
description:
Audit .beads/security-constraints.bead for consistency with security-related spike findings:

## Spike Findings to Integrate:

### Q8 (Fake Bot Defense):
- PoW difficulty: 18 (~30s registration)
- Rate limiting: Accept some Sybil risk initially
- Cost-benefit: 30s acceptable for legitimate bots

### Q9 (Chunk Verification):
- Challenge-response protocol: SHA-256(nonce || chunk_sample)
- Sample size: 256 bytes
- Latency: < 1ms
- Replay resistance: Nonce-based freshness

### Q13 (Fairness Verification):
- Spot check rate: 1% per write
- Phase 0: Warn on failures, no immediate bans
- Phase 1+: Reputation scoring + soft deprioritization
- False positive rate: < 1% (achieved: 0%)

## Update Requirements:
- Add PoW registration constraints
- Add challenge-response verification protocol
- Add fairness verification requirements
- Document acceptable security trade-offs for Phase 0
- Update threat model with validated defenses

## Deliverables:
- Updated .beads/security-constraints.bead
- Document changes in commit message

## Related Docs:
- docs/spike/q8/RESULTS.md
- docs/spike/q9/RESULTS.md
- docs/spike/q13/RESULTS.md

title: Create docs/PERSISTENCE.md comprehensive guide
description:
Create comprehensive persistence architecture document based on Spike Week 2 findings:

## Document Structure:

### 1. Overview
- Why persistence is needed
- Reciprocal persistence network concept
- Key guarantees (durability, confidentiality, integrity, availability, fairness)

### 2. Architecture
- Two-layer design (trust state + persistence fragments)
- Chunking model (64KB chunks, Q12)
- Holder selection (rendezvous hashing, Q11)
- Discovery (registry-based, Q7)
- Distribution (contracts Phase 0, Q14)

### 3. Protocols
- Registration protocol (PoW, Q8)
- Chunk distribution protocol (Q14)
- Verification protocol (challenge-response, Q9, Q13)
- Recovery protocol

### 4. Security
- Threat model
- Sybil resistance (Q8)
- Chunk verification (Q9)
- Fairness enforcement (Q13)
- Encryption (ACI keys)

### 5. Implementation
- Phase 0 design (validated by spikes)
- Phase 1+ optimizations
- Integration points
- Testing guidance

### 6. References
- Link to all spike RESULTS.md files
- Link to relevant beads
- Link to .cursor/rules

## Deliverables:
- docs/PERSISTENCE.md (comprehensive guide)
- Clear, technical documentation
- Suitable for implementation teams

## Related Docs:
- docs/spike/SPIKE-WEEK-2-BRIEFING.md
- All Spike Week 2 documentation
